fields.summary: UI (or new default option) to allow Tomcat to follow hyperlinks in JIRA Standalone Server

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-14257].
  {panel}

At present you can generate a user activity report for a single user.  It would be cool if you could enter a group, such as atlassian-developers and get a report detailing the number of issues assigned to each member of the group, grouped by project. (IE:  The current User Workload Report for each user in the group, in a long list of users).

Developer A (105 issues):
   Project A:   103 issues
   Project B:    2 issues

Developer B (230 issues);
   Project B:   200 issues
   Project C:   30 issues

etc.

Clicking on '### issues' for any user/project should take you to a a filter of the issues assigned to that user under the specific project.  Clicking on the total number of issues next to the user's name would take you to a filter of all issues assigned to that user.
fields.summary: User Workload Report by Groups

fields.summary: NPE on custom field deletion

fields.description:
We get lots of requests to create new projects, "configured in the same way as project X". For the various schemes this is not much trouble, although a "clone project" feature wouldn't go amiss.

Setting up the custom fields though is a royal pain. We have x custom fields, of which a project might use up to 20. This means clicking through each custom field and adding the new project as a context. This alone is dangerous, as it's easy to deselect existing projects if you are not familiar with it. Because you need to hold the control key it means you cannot type the first letter(s) in IE anyway, so it's a manual and tedious process.

I suggest a "custom field scheme", where you can say these issues types are associated with these fields, and then simply associate the scheme with the project. 

This is related to the linked issue but I didn't think the linked issue was that clear (no offence).
fields.summary: custom field "scheme" to help dealing with new project requests

fields.description:
When you move a subtask from an Issue Type where Security Level is a hidden field, to one where Security Level is no longer hidden, 
the system can mistakenly ask the User for a new Security Level.
This is only a minor issue, as then the subtask will not actually take on the chosen value - it will keep the Security Level of the parent.

In order to replicate this you may need to have a project with a Default Security Level.
fields.summary: Moving a subtask Issue Type will sometimes ask the user for a Security Level even though this value is inherited from the Parent Issue.

fields.description: When viewing a transition in the workflow editor, it shows the previous and next state. The text for the previous state is right-aligned, which makes it too close to the right border: !wfsteps.png! Here, thanks to firebug, is the HTML from the "previous" status: {code:html} Escalated {code} and the "next" state: {code:html} Resolved {code}
fields.summary: UI bug: text wrongly aligned in workflow editor

fields.description:
The following warning occurs on the confirm screen when you move an issue:
"Note: Sub-Tasks associated with this issue will lose data stored in fields not applicable in the target."

I believe that this is misleading to the user, as the stated issue will only occur if you move projects, however the text appears even if you only move the Issue Type.
fields.summary: The note on the "Move Issue" confirm screen is misleading.

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

1. Import the [CSV|^Test.csv] file and [Configuration|^conf.txt] file as attached to this issue
2. Go through the import wizard to import the issue
3. It uses the CSV header name as the new custom field name

At step 2 of 5, the new custom field name does not match with the name that being configured in the configuration file. Instead of using the customfield name from the configuration file, it takes the CSV header row name.
fields.summary: The CSV import wizard does not match the new custom field name based on the configuration file

fields.description:
So,

Once upon a time, I came across the JIRA footer at an open source project. I clicked through and played around. And it was good. To say the least. I learned some of the ins and outs and eventually was able to leverage that knowledge thanks to my fabulous company purchasing an Enterprise license and adopting it within EVERY department. I'm so excited that our Marketing people are using the word "ticket" outside of a concert venue.

Sadly, I'm not a *nix ninja. I might be that white belt in the corner, quivering in a pool of his own... output... But who can, when nobody's putting a lot of pressure on him, put up a decent enough fight.

As my organization and I have grown with JIRA, I've found myself with the cross hairs of many a UNIX admin on my face due to my attempt at scripting a file that basically accomodates my workflow as follows:

h2. Directory Structure
* {{/var/www/jira/}} symlinks to {{/var/www/alljiras/jira3121}} or whatever's newest
* I have a structure set up in {{/var/www/jira/alljiras/common}} that contains lovely things like
** A directory of custom images (not at all to imply Atlassian's selection of graphical representations are anything but fabulous)
** A custom directory of email templates and the accompanying mappings file.
** A bunch of plugins to be dumped in {{WEB-INF/lib}} and their corresponding (configured) properties files to be dumped in {{WEB-INF/classes}}
* Some other files that need to be overwritten (such as within {{secure}} or other JSPs)
* A list of morally objectionable newsgroup archives detailing how individuals of all types may pass their time using three vegetables, a bottle of Dr. Pepper and 3 sticks of gum

h2. Actually using it
So, I have a common directory that has files I know and love, and I'm all for symlinking (after telling tomcat in its {{server.xml}} file that I'm OK with that). So, here I sit, with a fresly-untarred version of JIRA 3.12.1 in {{/var/www/jira/alljiras/jira3121}} and a quasi-proprietary but arguably-logical organization of files in {{/var/www/jira/alljiras/common}}. Now, since I'm really giving my {{ln -s}} skills a run for their money, I've devised a script to go through and replace some of the more custom aspects of my configuration, such as:
* Symlinking my own {{email}} directory to {{WEB-INF/classes/templates/email}} as well as the {{email-template-id-mappings-or-whatever.xml}} file.
* Adding my own (aforementioned) spiffy images directory
* A few other visual tweaks on files that exist
* Overwriting (to the dismay of every Computer Science professor *EVER*) the config XML files (such as {{web}}, {{server}}, {{jira-application.properties}}, etc. etc.) with these "common" files. 
** Crossing my fingers that you crazy Atlassian folks didn't completely redesign the schema and cause life as we know it to vanish in a puff of logic.
* Copying all the plugins to the appropriate {{lib}} directories
** ...and their config files in their appropriate directoes.

h2. Making it less homicidally awful...
 
Now, several thoughts crossed my mind in this implementation,
# Maybe I could just overrwrite the files after doing some sort of visual confirmation or diff that the destination files are, by-and-large unchanged. *(This is what i sort of do, via removing, copying/symlinking, etc)
# If I was really fancy, maybe I could do something with {{diff}} and {{patch}} or some other text editing tool, based on the complexity of the file I wanted to grab.
# Hiring an intern, with his only job description being the management of our (arguably VERY customized) JIRA configuration and bringing me exotic coffee beans from occasion, along with three indigenous birds from their respective regions.

Sadly, interns aren't all they're cracked  up to be, and I think that a good investment of time to support enterprises who really customize JIRA up the wazoo (sorry for the coarse language) would be to have a "patch" system similar to your {{external-src}} directory.

If files can be {{patch}}ed somewhat intelligently (and you had bells, whistles and other epilepsy-inducing UI elements notifying users of a major change that would require a re-write) using an automated system, that'd be great.

I mean, even if we could set up a **common** JIRA directory structure with just the files that we changed (bonus points for making a script that would run and determine these changed files and send them to this **common** directory store), that would be a great first step.

And if we could have your talented team of developers come up with a way to generate {{patch}}-y esque {{diff}}s from this structure that could be injected into future JIRA instances, that'd be great too.

Of course, If I was Billy Bugfiler who had nothing better to do than whine about implementations at present, I'd suggest a slightly more modular approach to customizing templates and having them persist through version upgrades. Or maybe having more configuration items captured in the XML backup/restore procedure.

h2. The point of all this babble...

To summarize, it'd be swell if there could be some developments made as a part of JIRA or as a "plug in" that would permit users who heavily customize various aspects of their configuration to retain these changes through upgrades (within -- of course -- valid upgrade versions that don't employ completely new logic) and to apply this logic to brand-new installs. Even if you just provide a "makeJIRAPatchFile" and "applyJIRAPatchFile" scripts with some Atlassian Magic and leave us XML-fiddlers on our own to make our own scripts using these resources, I think it would be a great help and would assist in rapid adoption of your new (and much appreciated/anticipated/kick-ass) releases.

Thanks, ladies + gents!

-- 
Tim Feeley // MANHUNT Product Manager
Online Buddies, Inc // tfeeley@online-buddies.com
fields.summary: Upgrade without manual (re)placement of customized JSPs/Templates/Plugins, etc

fields.description:
Say we have two issue types, one is Software, the other is Hardware. If Software is selected, the available Component should ONLY be  Office , CADD etc. However, if Hardware is selected, the availabel Component turns to be like PC/Laptop, Printer etc.
It is really usefull for our company.

fields.description:
I have two tabs open in the browser, each showing a different dashboard page. When I try to do an operation _(move up, down, left, right, copy, delete or more to another page)_ with a portlet on the page that was not the last used _(current dashboard page)_ the operation blows up with a {{NullPointerException}}.

The exception indicates that the portlet was not found on the current page, which is stored in the session.
fields.summary: NullPointerException when moving portlet on the dashboard page

fields.description:
Hi,

I've manage to reproduce a bug in IE.

* Using IE7 and IE6
* Click on the 'Filters' link (even happens to our SAC on IE6 and IE7)
* After loading (complete load), close the window and click on the link again
* Continue doing that and the popup showing all the filters will drop out of the screen

From the javascript code {{jira-global-min.js}}, the function {{addOrAppendToValue}} keeps on appending a value to the x-axis and y-axis and then runs {{window.moveTo(x, y)}}.

Firefox however does not have this problem.  I do not know if it totally ignores the script but nothing happens while testing with Firefox.
fields.summary: Filters link refreshes till out of page

fields.description:
Firstly you need to have two different subtask issue-types that are not "compatible" with each other (eg use different Field Configurations).
Now edit one of these sub-tasks.
You will not be able to select a different issue-type in the edit page and it will have text saying
"There are no issue types with compatible field configuration and/or workflow associations.
The issue type can only be changed by moving this issue."

This includes a link to a URL looking like http://localhost:8090/jira/secure/MoveIssue!default.jspa?id=10060 but this URL is only valid for moving parent issues.
Subtask move needs to be something like http://localhost:8090/jira/secure/MoveSubTaskChooseOperation!default.jspa?id=10060.

Clicking the provided link will produce an error message:
  "Sub-tasks cannot be moved independently of the parent issue."
fields.summary: Cannot use the link in Issue Edit to move a subtask

fields.description:
If users hide the Resolution field in their field configuration, then subsequently resolved or closed issues do not have a resolution set.

This breaks the "Open: assigned to me" filter, which relies on the assumption that resolved or closed issues will have a resolution field set.

Until we come up with a more sophisticated indication of openness, I think we should enforce that Resolution cannot be hidden.
fields.summary: Should not be able to hide Resolution field
See history of changes made to a Version

fields.description:
It would be really handy if a user could soft delete a attachment, which basically removes the attachment in his/her point of view, but the actual attachment still exists. Deleted attachments should be recoverable (resurrection) by administrators. 

Having this feature will make sure attachments deleted on user error or easily recoverable, without digging though all backups.
fields.summary: permanently keep deleted attachment - attachment graveyard

fields.description: We need to add a method to the ChangeHistoryManager to getAllPreviousIssueKeys(issueKey) given an issueKey.  This is useful for SCM plugins that need to display changesets for an issue.  If the issue was moved (and therefore has a different issue key), we still want to be able to see changesets that were committed with the old issuekeys.
fields.summary: Add method to ChangeHistoryManager to return all previous issue keys of a given issue

fields.summary: The top navigation bars html is outside of the html body tag

fields.description:
Issue description:
We are using JIRA 3.11 (#288) Enterprise edition.
We installed the Charting & Reporting Plugin 1.3.10 at the time of the update to 3.11.

A user has a portlet making use of the Pie Chart report.
He views his dashboard, clicks on any of the slices in the chart, and his browser crashes (the "Windows Vista has detected a problem" warning appears and he has to relaunch).
The same report for the same user works fine in Windows XP.

Expected behavior:
The "slices" of the pie chart should not crash the browser when accessed on any platform.
fields.summary: Firefox crashes when clicking on Charting plugin's Pie Chart "slices" on Windows Vista

fields.description: I have set up about 50 groups, each corresponding to a customer.  The idea is to allow the customer to see all the support tickets related to them, not just the ones that individual might have reported.  Unfortunately, these 50 customer names do not display in alphabetical order which makes it extremely difficult to find the customer quickly.
fields.summary: Security Level Field does not sort its contents

fields.description:
In jira-application.properties, we say that JIRA should wait at most 30s to an index lock before giving up:

{noformat}
# Specified the 'wait time' for a file lock in the Lucene IssueIndexManager (in milliseconds)
# This value should only be modified if you are seeing a jira.issue.index.DefaultIndexManager 'Giving up reindex' ERROR
# in your log files or requested to do so by Atlassian support.
jira.index.lock.waittime=30000
{noformat}

For an average size JIRA (33k issues) on average hardware, JIRA's nightly index optimization takes 48s. On the ASF JIRA, 75k issues takes 208s. If any write operation takes place during this time it will fail.

Clearly, 30s hangs are not outside the bounds of possibility. Could we increase this to 300s or something?
fields.summary: Ensure the index optimize operation does not cause index lock timeouts

fields.summary: Exception in user-picker on EACJ

fields.description: When attaching files with .docx .xlsx .pptx .odt extensions, (files which are in the open document format), upon downloading the attachments again, the browser will attempt to save them as ZIP files in some cases (at least on IE in Windows). Instead, the browser should recognise the correct MIME type for the file and prompt accordingly ("this is a Word document", or similar).
fields.summary: Office 2007 attachments (open document format files) download as ZIP files on some browsers

fields.description:
I would be a really great improvement to be able to create different workflows/security schemes for tasks. At least in my company, tasks do not work the same as bugs. Developers use taks to track items that need to be completed for a project. There are 3 issues with this 

1) The workflow is differnet from a bug, something like (open, InProgress, Finished) would seem more approriate. The problem is that there is no "breaking up" of issues and this workflow will not work for bugs. 

2) One rule (which I believe should remain in place) is that only the testing group can close a bug. The problem here is that tasks are not bugs and testers have no idea if a task has been closed because in most cases there is no way to verify the competion of the task. 

3) Tasks show up in the release notes for the project much in the same way that bugs do, but tasks are not the same. In fact, most tasks should not be in release notes.
fields.summary: Different configurations for Tasks

fields.description:
The  Extra CSV Import Features (http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Extra+CSV+Import+Features) has some wrong information.  

{quote}* com.atlassian.jira.imports.csv.mappers.FirstInitialFirstNameUserMapper - Expects users that are in the format John Smith and creates users with the name johnsmith
* com.atlassian.jira.imports.csv.mappers.FullNameUserMapper - Expects users that are in the format John Smith and creates users with name jsmith{quote}

After doing some testing, I've found out that the results for these two results are inverted.  

Name used: John Smith
FirstInitialFirstNameUserMapper returns *jsmith*
FullNameUserMapper returns *johnsmith*

:)
fields.summary: "Extra CSV Import Features" has wrong information

fields.description:
There are many reasons that a bug would want to be in more than one project, but here are the biggest reasons: 
1. A bug applies to more than one simultaneous product. 
2. A bug gets reported in the wrong project, but the project where it got reported needs to wants to track it 
3. We tend to have lots of deferrals so closing and creating copies in new projects is tedious and inefficient. Bugs get lost, closed as dups of their copy, db gets bloated, etc. 
4. People can't see a reported in another project due to limitations of their privileges 

** Expected Result: 
We should be able to have the same bug appear in multiple projects and have project specific values for some fields such as: priority, assignee, state, resolution, comments. 

** Actual Result: 
We have to make copies and do lots of manual syncronizing of bug reports. There's lots of db bloat, bifurcation of comments, duplication of effort, inefficiency with bug searching, inefficiency with bug isolation, investigation, fixing, test case creation, etc. The list of inefficiencies in the organization is long because of the lack of this feature in the bug database.
fields.summary: Need to be able to assign a bug to multiple projects

fields.description:
It appears that some organizations reassign workflows quite frequently.  It is suspected that when you create a new workflow scheme and assign a project that has 1,000 issues to this new workflow scheme, 1,000 new entries are created in database's OS_WFENTRY table.  

The previous entries are "orphaned" and don't get cleaned up.

The purpose for the improvement is to help with disk space usage.  In one case, this table was reduced from 1GB to 5MB by cleaning up the orphaned entries manually.
fields.summary: Better cleanup of orphaned OS_WFENTRY table entries

fields.description:
It's been reported that IIS ISAPI Websphere plugin causes log-out problems in JIRA with Websphere 6.1.  When a user clicks the log-out button, they'll get a 500 error.

Connecting directly to Websphere avoids the problem.

In the JIRA logs, the following appears:

{code}

fields.description:
If project leaders have created version names which are very long, the selector box in the issue finder panel does not allow you to see the full name, the rightmost characters are truncated if they exceed the width of the selector box. 

This has caused issues in our environment when long release names have been created with the version string at the end (eg. 'Some long version name v0.0.2', 'Some long version name v0.1.0' etc..) It becomes impossible to select the correct version when trying to filter for a specific release. See the attached screenshot for an example (look for the highlighted selection box), in this case it is impossible to select the correct version since all four have the same prefix, not enough text is displayed to see the actual version number.

I can find some workarounds: In particular you can go via the project main page, selecting the 'releases' or 'versions' tabs and then preselecting the desired version. Alternatively you may know by experience which-is-which, you can also experiment until you find the correct version to select.
fields.summary: Long component or version names not fully displayed in Finder panel

fields.description:
In the various text files in JIRA (*.jsp, *.vm, *.css etc), some files end with a newline, some don't. This wouldn't matter in the slightest, except that:
 - Some editors (vim, gedit, but not IDEA, Eclipse, emacs) will automatically add a newline when saving a file. [Wikipedia|http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newline] says "The general convention on most systems is to add a newline even after the last line, i.e., to treat newline as a line terminator."
 - 'diff' expects each line to end with a newline character, and generates a spurious diff block if it doesn't find it:
{noformat}
/tmp/atlassian-jira-enterprise-3.12.1-standalone/atlassian-jira$ diff logout.jsp.orig logout.jsp
11a12
> test modification
33c34
< </html>
\ No newline at end of file
---
> </html>
{noformat}

In the interests of making JIRA patchers' lives a bit easier, we should standardize on newlines at the end of text files.
fields.summary: Make newlines in JIRA source files consistent

fields.description:
If there are currently no projects in JIRA (fresh install) and you try to import bugs from Bugzilla after entering the database information this error is presented:

"To perform this operation the default workflow must be active."

However, to make the default workflow active there must be projects present. This is a catch-22.

Please allow the importing from Bugzilla (and probably other issue trackers) when the default workflow is not active.

I did find workaround which is annoying to have to do but gets the job done. The workaround is to create a junk project, assign the default workflow to it, do any necessary import and then delete the junk project.

This is only necessary when there are no projects, once you have at least one project it is not an issue.
fields.summary: Importing from Bugzilla should be allowed even when the default workflow is not active

fields.description:
The thread local caching permissionManager maintains a cache of projects for which a user has the browse permission.  Unfortunately the cache does not take the user into consideration, and the getProjects(Permission, User) method may return incorrect results if two different users make subsequent requests within the same thread.

This can happen if subscriptions are being mailed out.  If two subscriptions for 2 different users are being sent at exactly the same time, one of them may be empty even though it should contain some issues.  This happens because the subscription in question, will retrieve projects used for the previous subscription to build up its permissions lucene query.

We should make the ThreadLocalPermissionManager respect the user when caching.  We should also make sure the mail sender cleans up threadlocal caches properly when sending mail.
fields.summary: ThreadLocalCachingPermissionManager does not cache project permissions user specific

fields.description:
As a test, I set up JIRA 3.12.1 and Confluence 2.7, and attempted to tell JIRA to trust Confluence. This is the error I got:

!trustederror.png!

For the purposes of this bug, i don't care _why_ it isn't working. I care that:

 - The error message presented to the user is completely unhelpful.
 - There is _absolutely nothing_ in the logs.

JIRA code is swallowing a NPE, which ought to be a hanging offense.

If I try the http URL instead of https, I get an equally uninformative message:

!trusted_doesnotsupport.png!

It's Confluence 2.7 which does indeed support the Trusted Application protocol. Again, a complete lack of information necessary to aid further debugging.
fields.summary: Terrible error reporting when establishing trusted connections

fields.description:
see http://www.bugzilla.org/docs/2.20/html/userpreferences.html:
 "Users to watch". When you enter one or more comma-delineated user accounts (usually email addresses) into the text entry box, you will receive a copy of all the bugmail those users are sent (security settings permitting). This powerful functionality enables seamless transitions as developers change projects or users go on holiday.

In addition this allows managers/leads to be aware of all traffic related/waiting on their reports.

JIRA doesn't allow this, which is a shame.

leads can get notification based on component leadership, or various other notification mechanisms, but nothing that allows monitoring all traffic another user gets. 

A clunky workaround is to create a filter for bugs reported/assigned to a group and subscribe to that report. if by RSS this will work, although many people still like email instead of rss...
If by email subscription by default the full filter results are sent, not the deltas since the last invocation. The only workaround here is to set the filter to only show differences in the period of time equal to the subscription frequency. As I said, clunky.

It will be much better to be able to define a list of users/groups you are watching, or at least to define the "lead" for each user so another user can get all their JIRA email traffic.
fields.summary: Allow receiving notifications on behalf of other users - similar to "User Watching" in bugzilla

fields.description:
SETUP
1. Create an issue with a description "foo:bar"
2. Create a second issue with a description "foo-bar"
3. Create a third issue with a description "foo=bar"

TEST
3. Do a search for the first issue with the search term "foo\:bar" (no matter if  it is with or without the quote) in the text search query field.
4. Do a search for the second issue with the search term "foo\-bar"
5. Do a search for the third issue with the search "term "foo=bar"

VALIDATION
6. Notice how the search terms change for the given query under Text Search Query in both 3 and 4 to "foo\ bar"
7. Notice how the search terms does NOT change in 5. The query under Text Search Query stays the same, as "foo=bar"
8. Notice how the result for 3, 4 and 5 find all 3 issues even if in the case 3 only the first issue should match, in case 4 only the second issue should match and in 5 only the third issue should match
9. Notice that the same happens for a query without escaping the special characters ":" and "-".
10. Notice that the same happens for a query when escaping the non-special character "="

I noticed this when using a customfield that uses the text search. The "=" character being the problem. It matches my delimiter I used (":") even if it should not. Also the customfield query with "\:" or "\-" does NOT change to "\ " but stays the same when performing the search.


SUGGESTED FIXES
1. Do not change the given query ("\:" to "\ ")n in the text search
2. Do not match any special character and "=" with the query "\ ", "\-" and "\:" (possibly also other special characters)
3. Do not match special characters with "="
fields.summary: Search matches too much: Using special characters and = in text field such as description

fields.description:
If we have a Jelly script, running a filter that results >1 issue, and transitioning them, eg:

{code:xml}
<JiraJelly xmlns:jira="jelly:com.atlassian.jira.jelly.enterprise.JiraTagLib" xmlns:core="jelly:core" xmlns:log="jelly:log">
        <jira:RunSearchRequest filterid="10020" var="issues" />
        <core:forEach var="issue" items="${issues}">
            <log:warn>Transitioning issue ${issue.key}</log:warn>
            <jira:TransitionWorkflow key="${issue.key}" workflowAction="Resolve Issue"/>
        </core:forEach>
</JiraJelly>
{code}

Then all transitioned issues will have their assignee set to that of the first encountered issue.
fields.summary: Jelly TransitionWorkflow tag in forEach loop sets wrong assignees

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-14162].
  {panel}

this is related to http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/issue_creation_email.html 

we have multiple projects on our server, each of which has an email address which users can send mail to and create a defect report in that project.
The problem is that createusers only creates a standard set of permissions regardless of the e-mail address the user sent to. 
(i.e. the new user is added to whatever groups are defined for Administration --> Global Permissions --> JIRA Users )

What we need is a way that a user sending to proj_A@myCompany.com is created as a member of the groups jira-users and projectA-users,
while a user sending to proj_B@myCompany.com is created as a member of the groups jira-users and projectB-users.

We need this due to the privacy concerns that some of our customers have for their products (which we develop for them).

Note that this is somewhat related to http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-10364 but not exactly, since some of our customers prefer to use their personal e-mail addresses when creating accounts. 
 
While there may be cleaner ways to resolve this, one possible way occurs to me:
the developer would optionally define another handler parameter when using the createusers=true parameter. let's call is additionalgroup for the sake of example.

the ProjectA_Service would have handler.params defined similar to: .... createusers=true, additiaonalgroup=projectA-users, catchemail=proj_A@myCompany.com ....

the ProjectB_Service would have handler.params defined similar to: .... createusers=true, additiaonalgroup=projectB-users, catchemail=proj_B@myCompany.com ....

both of these services would pass their respective additionalgroup values to the service that actually creates the user in Jira.
As a result , the JIRA Users permission under Global Permissions would only include the jira-users group.
fields.summary: email service: createusers=true creates same user permissions regardless of address defect report was sent to.

fields.summary: Delete notifications cause NPE

fields.description:
The first thing many users see in JIRA is the text "Not a member? Signup for an account."

"Sign up" is what you do to get an account. "Signup" is.. some horrible made-up noun describing the result of signing up?

Likewise we abuse "log in". The Use permission is described as "Ability to login to JIRA".

Login is a noun, log in is phrasal verb.
fields.summary: Change "signup" to "sign up", "login" to "log in", etc

fields.description:
When using the pie chart filter and sorting on something like Impact (1-4) or Priority (A-D), the slices of the chart are not ordered in alphabetic or numeric order, but rather by percentage.

This makes side-by-side comparisons useless, as the slice colors do not match up.

Ideally there would be an option to sort slices by key, as opposed to percentage.
fields.summary: Slices in Pie Charts should be sortable in order other than percentage

fields.description:
When attempting to create or edit an issue with Safari, and then clicking on create/update button, you will get a 404 response page from Jira. The issue creation/updating actually happens, just only the redirection back to the issue causes the problem, and only right after submitting the form. Hitting refresh will reload the target issue page correctly.

{panel:title=Error Message}
HTTP Status 404 - No view for result [error] exists for action [ViewIssue]

type Status report

message No view for result [error] exists for action [ViewIssue]

description The requested resource (No view for result [error] exists for action [ViewIssue]) is not available.

Apache Tomcat/5.5.20
{panel}
fields.summary: Editing or creating an issue with Safari  3.0.4 gives 404 error

fields.description:
It would be nice if you could describe a dependency from one project version to another. A good example of this is a complex web application. The web application likely has a JIRA project of it's own. It may have several components that are also setup as JIRA projects. Using the *component* section of a project isn't always useful as the component details vary from the project details and the component might be shared among projects.

In any case, you could then associate Component 1.x.x as a dependency to Project 1.x.x.

This would be very useful when trying to see a summary view of all oustanding issues for an end product.

Our current workaround is to create an issue in Project 1.x.x that is called "Integrate Component  1.x.x". You can then link this issue all of the Component 1.x.x issues. As you can imagine, this can be time consuming.
fields.summary: Project to Project Dependencies
show previous comments transitions
Jelly backwards-compatibility broken - commentLevel attribute removed

fields.description:
Seems that we have a user which has spotted this inconsistency.  

* http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/v3.12/usermanagement.html#Deleting+a+User

{panel}Rather than deleting a user, it is recommended to disable their account by removing them from all groups (see 'Assigning a User to a Group', above). This prevents the user's account from being used, {color:red}and prevents the user's name appearing in User Pickers ('Assignee', etc){color}. It is still important to reassign any issues assigned to that user, but there is no need to modify the 'Reporter' as described below.{panel}

The documentation is slightly incorrect where by after removing the user from all group(s), the user is still able to be chosen from the user picker list.  This is one of the improvement request which is being tracked.

* http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-11156
fields.summary: User picker still shows user after being removed from all groups

fields.description: With the charting plugin turned on, do a search that filters for a specific project, component, and test query term.  Then click 'Charts'.  The number of issues graphed will be the number of issues returned in the filter if you remove the text query term.   The text query term seems to be ignored by the charting plugin.

fields.description:
When there are multiple user accounts with the same real name, the drop-down user selector displays duplicate entires for each, with no way to distinguish them.  It would be nice if it also displayed the username in this case.

(This can happen when, for example, a user has a JIRA account but also opens an issue by email from a different address.)
fields.summary: Duplicated user real names confuse user selector

fields.description:
I managed to reproduce with the following steps:

1. Import the attached [CSV file|^test.csv]
2. At step 2 of 5, map the CSV header row with the corresponding JIRA field

It never go to step 3 instead redirect the page to "CSV Import Wizard: Setup" and it does not display any error messages.

However, when I try to remove 1 of the bracket in the header row, it does go to step 3 and successfully created the issue.
fields.summary: CSV Importer does not escape extra brackets '()' in the field header while doing the mapping
SchedulerUtil is a robustness bug - It wont started scheduler if the jobs data is invalid

fields.description:
Currently JIRA provides a 'Sub-Task Blocking Condition' workflow condition. When including this you must select all statuses that sub-tasks may be in for the transition to proceed. The basic assumption of this implementation is that a blocking condition will primarily exist during 'Closed' type transitions, and sub-tasks must first be closed.

I'm requesting an improvement to allow the sub-task blocking condition to apply only to sub-tasks of a particular issue type. 

The following is our use case:

We have subtasks "Customer Build", "Finance Order", "IT Process", "Support Query", etc
Each of subtasks uses a workflow including the following statuses: "New", "Open", "In Progress", "Ready for QA", "Closed"

We want our parent issue only to transition if all 'Customer Build' subtasks have been closed, regardless of the state of other subtasks. With the current implementaiton this is not possible. 

One possible workaround is to have the 'Customer Build' subtask use entirely unique statuses. This would allow the condition to, for example, require a 'Customer Build Closed' status as well as every possible status of non Customer Build workflows. This is less then ideal and having more complex criteria for this condition would be useful.
fields.summary: Allow Issue Type restrictions on 'Sub-Task Blocking Condition' workflow condition

fields.description: Currently when you import issues from MANTIS, you lose all of the change history associated with that issue.  I think in the future it would be a good idea to add the ability to keep all of this history.
fields.summary: Importing Mantis History

fields.description:
It would be very handy if you could find issues based on the parent task id.  This would allow bulk editing.  

In an addition, a link on the parent task page that would list a subtasks that could be exported.
fields.summary: Find and report on issues by Parent Task

fields.description:
We currently have two Perforce servers but one JIRA installation that handles both Perforce servers. Or, rather, we'd like it to.

What we'd like to be able to do is have named Perforce server configurations and allow us to assign a particular project to a particular Perforce server, with a default applied as well.

For example, we might have two Perforce configurations:
- London
- Tokyo
And three projects:
- ProjA <-- Explicitly put against London
- ProjB <-- Explicitly put against Tokyo
- ProjC <-- Set to London because it's the default installation
fields.summary: Support multiple perforce repositories in the same JIRA installation

fields.description:
From customer report:
{quote}
url: https://jira.ts.wikimedia.org/browse/WIKISENSE-13#action_10507

Hi!

At the url you will find:

לערי ריינהארט - 10 December 2007 04:48:23
and
לערי ריינהארט - 10 December 2007 04:18:12

As you can see the user name, the separation mark and the timestamp are not separated properly.

the username is
לערי ריינהארט
the separation mark is
-
the timestamps are
10 December 2007 04:48:23
and
10 December 2007 04:18:12

You may find details about « remedy against BiDi interference caused by the (arbitrary) content of various fields » at

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=406406
B u g 406406 - remedy against BiDi interference caused by the (arbitrary) content of various fields

Best regards Reinhardt [[user:Gangleri]]
{quote}

I managed to reproduce the problem in JIRA version 3.12. Step to reproduce this bug:

* Change the full name to [Bi-directional text|http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bi-directional_text], sample לערי ריינהארט
* Comment on the issue and it will display separation in between the full name and time stamp.
fields.summary: BiDi (bidirectional) issues: items in an enumeration list should stay separated regardless of their BiDi content

logwork.start.date

Data rozpoczęcia

Please ensure the file is java2ascii'ed properly, to ensure the ę is encoded as a \u escape.
fields.summary: Update the Polish translation for Start Date for Log Work screen

fields.description: We have security requirements that passwords must contain a combination of upper/lower case, numbers and special characters and be changed every 30 days. JIRA doesn't allow any checking of passwords or force the user to change it.
fields.summary: Add ability to force password standards such as numbers, letters and special characters and force the user to change based on time

fields.description:
Many of our customers are not aware if a new release of JIRA has been made. It would be nice if we can display in the footer or in the license section a small note which informs the user that a new release (version 3.xxx) is now available.

The URL from where JIRA fetches this information could be listed in the external-links.properties file so that we can show the current JP version number to Japanese customers.

This would encourage the users to renew their licenses since a number of our customers are not even aware that a new version is available. Also, this could be handy when we make a security update and would like the customers to know about it.
fields.summary: How about displaying the latest JIRA version number from within the application?

fields.description:
Currently if input is entered into the Comments textarea similar to this description field, if the user navigates away to another site (accidentally, eg to homepage), the contents of the comment box is lost (it's possible to return and re-click 'comment' to return the textarea).

A customer has suggested a javascript warning popup box would be a nice UI addition (similar to when you attempt to close a tab/page when ANY input has taken place in a textarea.
fields.summary: warn users when accidentally changing URLs away when text exists in comment textarea

fields.description: A customer has suggested that including the size of the permgen allocated size (current + max) in the System info page would encourage correct self diagnosis of an OutOfMemory JIRA installation. It makes sense on those occasions to check the system info page on next reload to see how much Memory JIRA has - a nice bar graph of permgen would certainly accelerate/highlight fault resolution from a support and/or customer perspective.
fields.summary: add permgen memory allocation size to system info page

fields.description:
I am in need to invoke certain operation screens on transition.   Currently I am able to add the Attach File to a screen and all related buttons and functionality for uploading a file work.

I would also like to use work log, Clone, Link,  and plug ins that add an Operation to the screen.  Specifically the Clone and Move plug in to be used as the last transition in our help desk project.  This would allow us to easily display a screen to clone, move, comment, Link.

I believe this is related to JRA-7661and hope you will consider trying to squeeze this in 4.0.  This is related to JRA-9564 dealing with help desk. 

Without this capability, it is nearly impossible to use Jira as a proper Help Desk system seemlessly move issues from help desk project to a programming project or even the example you give on your own website on moving the issue from one project for tier 1 to another for tier 2.
fields.summary: Allow WorkFlow transistion Screen to take advantage of Operation screens.
